title: 108_s2329
content: The Act is titled the "Scott Campbell, Stephanie Roper, Wendy Preston, Louarna Gillis, and Nila Lynn Crime Victims' Rights Act." It amends Title 18 of the United States Code by adding a new chapter on Crime Victims' Rights. The "Scott Campbell, Stephanie Roper, Wendy Preston, Louarna Gillis, and Nila Lynn Crime Victims' Rights Act" adds a new chapter on Crime Victims' Rights to Title 18 of the United States Code. Crime victims have rights including protection from the accused, notice of public proceedings, the right to be heard, confer with the government attorney, restitution, proceedings free from delay, and fair treatment. The "Scott Campbell, Stephanie Roper, Wendy Preston, Louarna Gillis, and Nila Lynn Crime Victims' Rights Act" ensures crime victims are treated with fairness, dignity, and privacy in court proceedings. The court must guarantee victims' rights, and government officials must make efforts to notify and protect crime victims. In cases of conflict between the prosecutor and the victim, the victim's rights prevail. The prosecutor must advise the crime victim of any conflict of interest and direct them to appropriate legal assistance. Notice of release may be withheld if it endangers anyone's safety. The crime victim, their representative, and the government attorney can assert rights under the Act, but the accused cannot benefit from it. In cases with multiple victims, the court may find it challenging to address all their rights. If the number of crime victims makes it impracticable to give all victims the rights in this chapter, the court will create a procedure to implement these rights. A Federal court denying a crime victim's right can be challenged through a writ of mandamus. The Government can appeal a district court's denial of a crime victim's right in a criminal case. In no case shall a failure to afford a right under this chapter provide grounds for a new trial. Nothing in this chapter authorizes a cause of action for damages. The term 'crime victim' refers to a person directly harmed by a Federal offense. Legal guardians or representatives may assume the rights of a crime victim who is under 18, incompetent, incapacitated, or deceased. The defendant cannot be named as such guardian or representative. The Attorney General will establish regulations to enforce crime victims' rights and ensure compliance by officials. This includes setting up an administrative authority to handle complaints and mandating training for Department of Justice employees. The Attorney General will establish regulations to enforce crime victims' rights, including disciplinary sanctions for employees who fail to comply with Federal law. The final decision on complaints will be made by the Attorney General with no judicial review. The Attorney General will make the final decision on complaints with no judicial review available to the complainant. SEC. 3. INCREASED RESOURCES FOR ENFORCEMENT OF CRIME VICTIMS' RIGHTS. Amends the Victims of Crime Act of 1984 to include Crime Victims Legal Assistance Grants. The Director may provide grants to various entities for the enforcement of crime victims' rights. Amounts collected under the False Claims Act can also be used for these grants. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2005-2009. The Director may provide grants to entities for crime victims' rights enforcement. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2005-2009 to support Victim/Witnesses Assistance Programs, enhance the Victim Notification System, provide staff for the National Crime Victim Law Institute, and fund the Office for Victims of Crime. The Office for Victims of Crime provides support for the National Crime Victim Law Institute and similar organizations to offer counsel for victims in criminal cases. Grants are also given to develop state-of-the-art systems for notifying crime victims of important dates and developments. The Victims of Crime Act of 1984 is amended to include provisions for notifying crime victims of important dates and developments. The Victims of Crime Act of 1984 is amended to include provisions for notifying crime victims through grants. The Director may grant funds to various entities to develop systems for notifying crime victims of important dates and developments in criminal proceedings. These systems can be integrated with existing case management systems. Additional funds may be appropriated for this purpose. Funds totaling $25 million are allocated for fiscal years 2005 to 2009 for grants under the False Claims Act. Amounts collected under the False Claims Act can be used for grants under this section, subject to appropriation. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts must report annually to Congress on the denial of rights in criminal cases under chapter 237 of title 18, United States Code. The General Accounting Office will conduct a study on the impact of amendments on crime victims in the Federal system. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress containing the results of a study conducted within 3 years of the enactment of this Act. The Senate passed the bill on April 22, 2004. Attest: EMILY J. REYNOLDS, Secretary.
